**Biden Signs Emergency Appropriations Bill to Prevent US Government Shutdown**
US President Biden signed an emergency appropriations bill to prevent the US government from 'shutting down'. The latest bill will continue to provide funding for the US government until March 2025, avoiding a partial shutdown of federal agencies in the US East Coast after 21:00 on December 21. The new bill is almost identical to the one that failed to pass on December 19, but it has deleted the part related to the debt ceiling. It leaves three main parts: a short-term extension of government spending, billions of dollars in disaster relief funds, and additional aid to farmers. The US Congress had previously voted to pass the bill. The US Congress worked late into the night on December 20 and voted to pass the short-term spending bill at 1:00 am on December 21. Just a few hours earlier, the House of Representatives had passed the bill. The White House has stopped preparing for a government shutdown. The US government's operating funds should come from the annual budget appropriation, but the US Congress usually passes a new annual appropriation bill before the new fiscal year begins on October 1. However, due to intense partisan struggles in recent years, they often fail to reach an agreement in time, and Congress passes a short-term spending bill to temporarily maintain the operation of the federal government. Even short-term spending bills cannot avoid partisan calculations, and a budget bill usually undergoes multiple revisions until both parties agree on it. After negotiations between Democrats and Republicans, and partly referring to former President Trump's proposal, the final bill was revised and passed. The bill allows the federal government to maintain its current spending level until March 14, 2025, and includes $100 billion in disaster relief funds and $10 billion in aid to farmers. However, the latest bill does not include the provision to raise the debt ceiling, which was requested by former President Trump. The debt ceiling is the maximum amount of debt that the US Congress has set for the federal government to fulfill its existing payment obligations, currently at $3.14 trillion. On June 3, 2023, President Biden signed a bill to temporarily suspend the debt ceiling until early 2025, temporarily avoiding the US government's debt default. The bill also limits US government spending for the 2024 and 2025 fiscal years. According to data released by the US Department of the Treasury in late November 2024, the US federal government's debt has reached $36 trillion, far exceeding the current debt ceiling limit of $31.4 trillion. If the US federal government cannot extend the debt ceiling deadline or raise the debt ceiling, the government will inevitably default on its debt. On December 17, the US House of Representatives released a draft of the short-term spending bill, which had been agreed upon by both parties. On December 18, former President Trump suddenly announced his opposition to the 1.0 version of the bill, saying that he would not agree to the bill unless the Democratic Party 'terminates or extends the debt ceiling'. After Trump's opposition, the House of Representatives canceled the vote on the bill scheduled for December 18. In a joint statement on social media, Vice President Harris said that Congress should pass a 'clean' appropriations bill, rather than meeting all the demands of the Democratic Party. The statement also urged Republicans to pressure Democrats to agree to raise the debt ceiling. At the same time, White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre released a statement saying that Republicans must stop playing politics with temporary appropriations bills. After the 1.0 version was vetoed by Trump, House Speaker Mike Johnson and others sought an alternative plan, adding Trump's requested debt ceiling increase provision and removing some unrelated provisions, giving birth to the 2.0 version of the short-term spending bill. On December 19, the US House of Representatives voted on the bill, but it failed to pass due to a lack of the required two-thirds majority. House Republican leaders had to negotiate with Democratic leaders again. Finally, on December 20, just hours before the federal government was set to shut down, the House of Representatives reached an agreement with the Democrats, and the new short-term spending bill was passed. According to reports, the latest bill is almost identical to the one that failed to pass on December 19, but it has deleted the part related to the debt ceiling, leaving three main parts: a short-term extension of government spending, billions of dollars in disaster relief funds, and additional aid to farmers. In recent years, the US two parties have repeatedly engaged in 'extreme budget struggles' and 'last-minute maintenance' of the federal government, with the government shutting down for 34 days in 2018-2019 during Trump's first term. According to estimates, the shutdown caused a loss of approximately $3 billion to the US economy. The White House has stopped preparing for a government shutdown.
